Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column isused in conjunction with STEP_SEQ_NO2 and STEP_SEQ_NO. This column allowsfor complex trackingsuch as tracking two steps occurring simultaneously or if stepsare needed to be added to the initial procedure.
Column Comment.3: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column isused in conjunction with STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO. This column allowsfor complex tracking such as tracking two steps occurring simultaneously or if stepsare needed to be added to the initial procedure.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first comes into effect.
Column Comment.6: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row is no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.7: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.8: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.9: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.10: REASON: A narrative description explaining why the column STEP_SEQ_NO is notenough to capture what is happening in the analysis and how the two columnsSTEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 will help.
Column Comment.11: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.12: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.13: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.14: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.15: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.16: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.17: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
